repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Implement setup.cfg to hold config for flake8.  Kept that config pretty minimal for the time being.  (If cython wants to put linting in the CI, it might be worth looking at statsmodels's lint.sh since statsmodels is in a similar situation vis-a-vis linting)

Side-note about setup.cfg: it can subsume .coveragerc and tox.ini if desired.  I'm not sure about pylintrc, but wouldn't be surprised.

Cleaned up the Plex directory.  Mostly (but not completely) ignored flake8 complaints about line length and module formatting.  Ignored 2 complaints about methods being too complex and 2 complaints about comparisons in Plex/Regexps.py comparing type(x) = ... instead of isinstance(x, ...) since I don't know if these are intentional.

comment_data.body: You're aware that we have a 120 character line limit? (See `pylintrc`)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -29,22 +26,27 @@ def nfa_to_dfa(old_machine, debug=None):
     # is reached.
     new_machine = Machines.FastMachine()
     state_map = StateMap(new_machine)
+
     # Seed the process using the initial states of the old machine.
     # Make the corresponding new states into initial states of the new
     # machine with the same names.
     for (key, old_state) in old_machine.initial_states.items():
         new_state = state_map.old_to_new(epsilon_closure(old_state))
         new_machine.make_initial_state(key, new_state)
+
     # Tricky bit here: we add things to the end of this list while we're
     # iterating over it. The iteration stops when closure is achieved.
     for new_state in new_machine.states:
         transitions = TransitionMap()
         for old_state in state_map.new_to_old(new_state):
             for event, old_target_states in old_state.transitions.items():
                 if event and old_target_states:
-                    transitions.add_set(event, set_epsilon_closure(old_target_states))
+                    transitions.add_set(event,
+                                        set_epsilon_closure(old_target_states))

comment_data.body:
Aaah! Please don't switch to `.format()` formatting!
We use '%' formatting throughout the code base – for various (sometimes historical) reasons, but above all for better looking format strings of C's "{…}" blocks.
Is this really needed?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -337,3 +339,4 @@ def eof(self):
         Override this method if you want something to be done at
         end of file.
         """
+        pass

comment_data.body: Please don't change the code formatting here. It's much more readable and saves a lot of screen space to open a parenthesis on the right and have a single-step indent for the next line(s).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -147,12 +145,9 @@ def expect(self, c):
         if self.c == c:
             self.next()
         else:
-            self.error("Missing %s" % repr(c))
+            self.error("Missing {c}".format(c=repr(c)))
 
     def error(self, mess):
         """Raise exception to signal syntax error in regexp."""
-        raise RegexpSyntaxError("Syntax error in regexp %s at position %d: %s" % (
-            repr(self.s), self.i, mess))
-
-
-
+        raise RegexpSyntaxError("Syntax error in regexp %s at position %d: %s"
+                                % (repr(self.s), self.i, mess))

comment_data.body: I think it's good to switch comment headers to docstrings, but I think this should be done everywhere.

I think the slow/fast comments (and the alternative implementations) can all be removed. They were probably added during optimisation, but changing the implementation of "state" would require a very good reason now, with careful benchmarking, regardless of any comments.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -174,26 +170,30 @@ def run_machine_inlined(self):
         buf_len = len(buffer)
         b_action, b_cur_pos, b_cur_line, b_cur_line_start, b_cur_char, b_input_state, b_next_pos = \
             None, 0, 0, 0, u'', 0, 0
+
         trace = self.trace
         while 1:
-            if trace:  #TRACE#
-                print("State %d, %d/%d:%s -->" % (  #TRACE#
-                    state['number'], input_state, cur_pos, repr(cur_char)))  #TRACE#
+            if trace:
+                print("State %d, %d/%d:%s -->" % (
+                    state['number'], input_state, cur_pos, repr(cur_char)))
+
             # Begin inlined self.save_for_backup()
-            #action = state.action #@slow
-            action = state['action']  #@fast
+            # action = state.action   # @slow
+            action = state['action']  # @fast

comment_data.body: Why?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -187,14 +185,13 @@ def parse_token_definition(self, token_spec):
         if not isinstance(token_spec, tuple):
             raise Errors.InvalidToken("Token definition is not a tuple")
         if len(token_spec) != 2:
-            raise Errors.InvalidToken("Wrong number of items in token definition")
+            raise Errors.InvalidToken("Wrong number of items in "
+                                      "token definition")
+

comment_data.body: The code style information is read from `tox.ini` and enforced by the test runner via `pycodestyle`. See `runtests.py`.
Also: `%r`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -147,12 +145,9 @@ def expect(self, c):
         if self.c == c:
             self.next()
         else:
-            self.error("Missing %s" % repr(c))
+            self.error("Missing {c}".format(c=repr(c)))
 
     def error(self, mess):
         """Raise exception to signal syntax error in regexp."""
-        raise RegexpSyntaxError("Syntax error in regexp %s at position %d: %s" % (
-            repr(self.s), self.i, mess))
-

-
+        raise RegexpSyntaxError("Syntax error in regexp %s at position %d: %s"
+                                % (repr(self.s), self.i, mess))

comment_data.body: I guess that the intention of the line breaks here was to separate the actual arguments from the cached globals. That makes perfect sense to me, so please keep it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -50,10 +49,8 @@ def __init__(self, map=None, special=None):
             special = {}
         self.map = map
         self.special = special
-        #self.check() ###
 
-    def add(self, event, new_state,
-            TupleType=tuple):
+    def add(self, event, new_state, TupleType=tuple):

comment_data.body: `None` is a constant now, so this is a useless (de-)optimisation. Actually, in case `self.special` is an actual `dict`, it is even entirely unnecessary to pass the argument into `.get()` at all.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -84,15 +80,13 @@ def add_set(self, event, new_set,
         else:
             self.get_special(event).update(new_set)
 
-    def get_epsilon(self,
-                    none=None):
+    def get_epsilon(self, none=None):

comment_data.body: No, but I prefer to make it explicit.  Can revert if you have a strong preference.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -337,3 +339,4 @@ def eof(self):
         Override this method if you want something to be done at
         end of file.
         """
+        pass

comment_data.body: No, just wondering if that was something that flake8 would complain about.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -337,3 +339,4 @@ def eof(self):
         Override this method if you want something to be done at
         end of file.
         """
+        pass

comment_data.body: this was a line-length complaint.  will revert after updating the flake8 config to 120.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -187,14 +185,13 @@ def parse_token_definition(self, token_spec):
         if not isinstance(token_spec, tuple):
             raise Errors.InvalidToken("Token definition is not a tuple")
         if len(token_spec) != 2:
-            raise Errors.InvalidToken("Wrong number of items in token definition")
+            raise Errors.InvalidToken("Wrong number of items in "
+                                      "token definition")
+

comment_data.body: this one feels really awkward to me, but OK
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -50,10 +49,8 @@ def __init__(self, map=None, special=None):
             special = {}
         self.map = map
         self.special = special
-        #self.check() ###
 
-    def add(self, event, new_state,
-            TupleType=tuple):
+    def add(self, event, new_state, TupleType=tuple):

comment_data.body: This is only ever called in one place and no kwarg is pased.  So just remove the `none` kwarg altogether?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -84,15 +80,13 @@ def add_set(self, event, new_set,
         else:
             self.get_special(event).update(new_set)
 
-    def get_epsilon(self,
-                    none=None):
+    def get_epsilon(self, none=None):

comment_data.body: in a separate pass it might be worth making these private with underscores

Yeah… These days, one probably woudn't do this at all any more, and if I did, I'd at least prefix the names with underscores. But removing these "hacks" might have a performance impact, and this is only meant as a code style change.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -50,10 +49,8 @@ def __init__(self, map=None, special=None):
             special = {}
         self.map = map
         self.special = special
-        #self.check() ###
 
-    def add(self, event, new_state,
-            TupleType=tuple):
+    def add(self, event, new_state, TupleType=tuple):

comment_data.body: Will make sure to do that throughout Plex now.  Other directories will do in separate PRs.

> It's much more readable and saves a lot of screen space to open a parenthesis on the right and have a single-step indent for the next line(s).

Out of curiosity, is this an editor-specific behavior?  It isn't clear to me how screen space is affected.

Regardless, not worth arguing about; reverting.

comment_data.body: Yes, it can be removed. `self.special` is a `dict`, I checked.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -84,15 +80,13 @@ def add_set(self, event, new_set,
         else:

-    def get_epsilon(self,

comment_data.body: As long as the tests pass, it should be fine to rename them.

The difference is between an indentation of 4 and an indentation of, say, 20, 40 or 60. What would you want to fit into a line that starts at character position 60? An indentation of 4 is entirely enough for the visual link, so I can see no reason to waste more horizontal space than that.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

commit.message: implement setup.cfg, lint cleanup of Plex directory
CLN: revert requested string formatting and line wrapping edits
